title: Worked Solution
text:
To express the given function \( h(x) $$=$$ $$4$$ + \sqrt[3]{x} \) in the form \( h(x) $$=$$ f(g(x)) \), we need to identify two functions \( f(x) \) and \( g(x) \) such that \( f(g(x)) $$=$$ $$4$$ + \sqrt[3]{x} \).

Let's look at the options you provided:

$$1$$. \( g(x) $$=$$ \sqrt[3]{x}, f(x) $$=$$ $$4$$ \): This option does not correctly represent \( h(x) \) because if \( g(x) $$=$$ \sqrt[3]{x} \), then \( f(x) \) must do more than just equal $$4$$ to reach the desired form of \( h(x) \).

$$2$$. \( g(x) $$=$$ $$x$$, f(x) $$=$$ $$4$$ + g(x) \): This option suggests that \( g(x) $$=$$ $$x$$ \) and \( f(x) $$=$$ $$4$$ + $$x$$ \). If we substitute \( g(x) $$=$$ $$x$$ \) into \( f(x) \), we get \( f(g(x)) $$=$$ $$4$$ + $$x$$ \), which does not match the given \( h(x) $$=$$ $$4$$ + \sqrt[3]{x} \) since it does not account for the cube root operation on \( $$x$$ \).

$$3$$. \( g(x) $$=$$ \sqrt[3]{x}, f(x) $$=$$ $$x^3$$ + $$4$$ \): In this option, \( g(x) \) correctly represents the cube root part of \( h(x) \), but the function \( f(x) $$=$$ $$x^3$$ + $$4$$ \) would cube the result of \( g(x) \) and then add $$4$$, which is not the structure of the given \( h(x) \).

$$4$$. \( g(x) $$=$$ \sqrt[3]{x}, f(x) $$=$$ $$4$$ + $$x$$ \): This option correctly identifies \( g(x) \) as the cube root part of \( h(x) \), and \( f(x) $$=$$ $$4$$ + $$x$$ \) correctly adds $$4$$ to the result of \( g(x) \). Thus, if you substitute \( g(x) \) into \( f(x) \), you get \( f(g(x)) $$=$$ $$4$$ + \sqrt[3]{x} \), which matches the given function \( h(x) \).

Therefore, the correct answer is \( g(x) $$=$$ \sqrt[3]{x}, f(x) $$=$$ $$4$$ + $$x$$ \), which accurately represents the given function \( h(x) $$=$$ $$4$$ + \sqrt[3]{x} \) as \( h(x) $$=$$ f(g(x)) \).
